t: All*pn night long on my bed I*ld looked for the one my heart loves; I*ld looked for him but did not find him.
I*ln will get up now and go about the city, through*ld its streets and squares; I*ln will search for the one my heart loves. So*ld I looked for him but did not find him.
The*ln watchmen found me as*ld they made their rounds in the city. “Have*ld you seen the one my heart loves?”

Scarcely*ln had I passed them when*ld I found the one my heart loves. I*ln held him and would not let him go till*ld I had brought him to my mother’s house, to*ld the room of the one who conceived me.
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ld the gazelles and by the does of the field: Do*ln not arouse or awaken love until*ld it so desires.
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness like*ld a column of smoke, perfumed*ln with myrrh and incense made*ld from all the spices of the merchant?
Look!*ln It is Solomon’s carriage, escorted*ld by sixty warriors, the*ld noblest of Israel,
all*ln of them wearing the sword, all*ld experienced in battle, each*ln with his sword at his side, prepared*ld for the terrors of the night.
King*ln Solomon made for himself the carriage; he*ld made it of wood from Lebanon.
Its*ln posts he made of silver, its*ld base of gold. Its*ln seat was upholstered with purple, its*ld interior inlaid with love. Daughters*ln of Jerusalem,
come out, and*ld look, you daughters of Zion. Look*ln on King Solomon wearing a crown, the*ld crown with which his mother crowned him on*ln the day of his wedding, the*ld day his heart rejoiced.
